title: Research help request: Type with unusual programming
content:
I am a design student working on my graduation thesis project. I plan to explore the development of a typeface that responds to variable factors of the user�s input. As a basic example, the weight or color of the face might change based on how fast it was entered by the user.   
   
I am interested in researching existing typefaces that have unusual programming to see what precedents have been set. I�ve scoped out the experimental section here on Typophile and looked at �random� fonts such as Beowolf and Flipper. I would greatly appreciate any suggestions of other typefaces to look at, or books/articles/web sites that might be relevant to my project.   
   
Thanks,   
Angela Wolak
author: wolaka

comments.content:
The Twin Cities typeface developed by Lettererror responds to the weather in Minneapolis/St Paul. See [http://www.letterror.com/portfolio/twin/index.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20060506050227/http:/www.letterror.com/portfolio/twin/index.html)   
   
You can see the font in action at [http://design.umn.edu:8080/cgi-bin/ltrstr/tcdc/alternator?page=interface\_004](http://web.archive.org/web/20060506050227/http:/design.umn.edu:8080/cgi-bin/ltrstr/tcdc/alternator?page=interface_004)

Some links that might be useful...   
   
The Alphabet Synthesis Machine   
 [http://alphabet.tmema.org/](http://web.archive.org/web/20060506050227/http:/alphabet.tmema.org/)   
   
Underware Typeworkshop   
 [http://www.typeworkshop.com/index.php?id1=workshops](http://web.archive.org/web/20060506050227/http:/www.typeworkshop.com/index.php?id1=workshops)   
   
MIT Students   
 [http://acg.media.mit.edu/courses/mas962/exhibition/](http://web.archive.org/web/20060506050227/http:/acg.media.mit.edu/courses/mas962/exhibition/)

Angela, this is a great topic! And the links mentioned above already cover a lot of ground.   
   
The one caution I would state early on is this: be careful to keep functionality always in sight - avoid turning things into self-serving formal aesthetic exercises.   
   
BTW, the "g" in Analogue makes me think you should be designing type.

How come i didn't know about this one?   
Good thing with Meeks's auto font maker is that the output is usable. (well for display copy anyway)

Just wanted to express my gratitude to those who have posted so far; it can be hard to find work of this quality just using google searches. These are some really interesting projects and I especially appreciate seeing the different interfaces that have been used to present the typefaces. Thanks again!

It works in DrawBot program (by sensei Erik van Blokland): DrawBotPixel font:
